text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person gathering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The examiner hopes that there is sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events. If they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Expect?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, etc., would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Bureau Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A work of exploration into the past

ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to measure a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The questionnaire is designed to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or supply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did You Answer This?", still will be willing to go by, please put a check mark here (X)

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires or other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All Questionnaires

Pioneer health conditions
Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
Pioneer housing
Pioneer education and churchwork
Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

[Stamp]
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: HECTOR ANDREW WATSON

2. Your address: 807 LIPSTON, SASK.

3. Date: MAY 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)

County of Perth

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

Charles Watson, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

May 24th, 1888

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

One year or two years lived in Manitoba near Winnipeg and Red River.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a child.")

I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

Father had only one hundred acres of land and they were no good land available, and he tried his best and found that there was nothing left to come west. When he and his wife decided to come west, they went out to find a homestead plot by the government. They found a homestead claim that was given to them by the government.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

I learned about the West through other people.

11. How much land did you come to work on?

There was lots of land. They came to work on it.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: HECTOR ANDREW WATSON
2. Your address: 80417 LITTLE RIVER, SASK.
3. Date: MAY 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Wallace, Saskatchewan
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Charles Watson, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   May 24th, 1884
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   One and a half or two years lived in Manitoba near Buhlow and Geraldton
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not.)
   I was in my teens
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Father had only two hundred acres of land and they were in poor shape. He thought he could make a better living in the West. When he decided to come West, he wrote each of his children a letter telling them how he intended to build up his fortune on his own. He called it a homestead and said that he was planning to be there for a long time.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

There was lots of land, they came to teach school.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought the family decision was sound.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Our family alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by train to Qu'Appelle Station when homeward bound on our way back to Regina. The train was not laid over at that time. It was filled with people from all over the world, including Norwegians who came in the car with us.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures or other excitement etc.)

The first Indians we met were in Butte Qu'Appelle.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan in 1912?

My family settled in Qu'Appelle and lived there until 1914.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We homesteaded in Butte Qu'Appelle.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We moved to Willow Bunch in 1914.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Answered in question No. 9. Farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought the family decision was sound.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What difficulties did you face during your journey west? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures or other excitement etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan in 1879?

16. Where did you settle or take up land in 1879-1880?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Answered in question No. 1. Farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

My mother wrote to them till nearly all of them.

20. If you got married, give end place of marriage.

My wife came west from Indiana.

21. Did anyone else come with me?

No child.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

My wife came from Indiana in 1873.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Poveshell farm was located for the first 20 years.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, I traveled extensively.

25. What kind of transportation did you use?

I used horseback and later a horse-drawn carriage.

26. How far did you travel by horseback?

I traveled up to 30 miles at a time.

27. How long did it take to travel by horseback?

It took about 3 hours to travel 30 miles.

28. How did you feel about the trip?

I felt very excited and adventurous.

29. What was the weather like during your trip?

The weather was mostly sunny and warm.

30. Did you encounter any difficulties during your trip?

I encountered some difficult terrain but overall it was smooth sailing.

31. How did you feel after completing your trip?

I felt accomplished and proud of my journey.

32. What did you learn from this experience?

I learned the importance of perseverance and determination.

33. How did this experience affect your life?

This experience taught me resilience and the value of hard work.

34. Would you recommend others to undertake such a journey?

Yes, I would encourage others to experience the joy of travel.

35. Any final thoughts?

Travel broadens the mind and opens up new horizons.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

My mother wrote to them very rarely after this.

20. If you got married, give place of marriage, date of marriage, name of spouse, and name of children.

My wife's parents came from England in 1883. They had five children.

21. Did anyone else come to settle? Yes, my brother came in 1884.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came here, tell when they came and where they settled.

My father came from England in 1883. He died in 1885.

23. Is there any particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

The first thing we did was to build a house.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, I traveled extensively.

25. What was the first religious service you attended?

The first religious service I attended was at the Baptist Church.

26. What was the first school you attended?

The first school I attended was in the town of [town name].

27. What was the first job you had?

My first job was as a [occupation].

28. What was the first thing you bought?

My first purchase was a [item].

29. What was the first thing you built?

My first building was a [structure].

30. What was the first thing you planted?

My first planting was [crop].

31. What was the first thing you raised?

My first raising was [animal].

32. What was the first thing you sold?

My first sale was [item].

33. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

34. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

35. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

36. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

37. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

38. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

39. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

40. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

41. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

42. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

43. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

44. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

45. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

46. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

47. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

48. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

49. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].

50. What was the first thing you bought from a store?

My first purchase from a store was [item].
19. How often did you visit family?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date.

21. Did anyone die in your household? If so, who and when?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West earlier than they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

24. What do you think about the future of the country?
How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

My mother wrote to them nearly all of them.

If you got married, give name and place of marriage.

My wife came west from Lydenham, Ontario, to teach the Raymond School in August 1899, and is still the teacher of the union. She was the second teacher to teach a winterschool and did so for three years.

Did anyone else come to settle?

But tell when they came and where they settled.

Alex Jim remained here from 1883 till they died. Alex died 1935. The rest of us all came on the train to Troy on South Line in 1884 & arrived in Fort Dalles on the 24th May 1884. All settled in July 23-1884.
How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

My mother wrote to them till nearly all of them passed on.

If you got married, give date and place of marriage.

Sept 18th at my farm. But I claim to be unmarried.

Did anyone else come to settle?

My wife came west from Lydenham, Ontario, to teach the Hayward school in August 1894, and is still the main spring of the union. She was the second teacher to keep a winter school and did so for these years.

2. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

Alex & Jim remained here from 1883 till they died. Jim died the fall of '84. Alex died 1935. The rest of us all came on the train to Troy on South Line Apples in 1884 & arrived in First Line Apples on the 24th of May 1884. All settled in Sec 23-13-2. W16, N-W16, East 1/2 20, SW 28, all in 23-13-2.
19. How often did you write to your mother?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Alex & Jim remained his farm 1883 till they died in the face of 1884. Alex died 1935. The rest of us all came on the train to Troy on South Dakota. Opie in 1884 & arrived in First Avenue on the 24th of May 1884. app. settled in 1884-1885.
19. How often did you write?

My mother passed on.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I got married in 1912 to Elizabeth Isabella Barclay. Sept 18th at my brother's house on SW¼-20-23-13-2. These west no children but I claim to have more nieces nephews & grandnieces nephews than anyone in Saskatchewan.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Not that I know of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Alex & Jim remained here from 1883 till they died. Jim died the fall of '84. Alex died 1935. The rest of us all came on the train to Troy on South Line Appelle in 1884 & arrived in Fort Appelle on the 24th of May 1884. All settled in Sep 23-13-2.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   About 1905 or 6

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   No car

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   First the office 15 miles, after 1904 by the 8th mile from our present house, 3 miles from the old house.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Till 1904, then in Lipton

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once or twice a week

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1930, more cars, more going to town, now it's Saturday nights.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Soon after Eaton & Simpson sent out their catalogs mostly clothing, boots, shoes, winter wear, etc., harness & harness supplies.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1915, the Lipton Rural Telephone Co., Lipton, Saskatchewan

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   It was the idea of making a permanent home for the family that made my father stay. At first if the country was good, no good try again. Out of twenty families that went there in 1883-1884 only 10 remained & the descendants of them are many & most of them within 20 miles from here. In BC after some in the old country.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

About 1905-6

26. If you owned a car before 1914, what did you buy? What made it so?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your house?

First Thousand House, 7 miles from the old town.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

Yes, 1906, then in 1914.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

Once or twice a week.

30. Then (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

About 1930, more cars, more buying.

31. Have (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

Most kind of articles did not buy in this way. Catalogs also were a fraction of prices. Purchases were made by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order.

32. Name of the catalogue's department store and the catalogue mostly clothing, boots, shoes, various needs, etc., towels, towels, towels.

33. Then did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Bell Telephone Co., Chicago branch.

34. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out?

It was an idea of making a permanent home for the family and buying a farm and try again.

35. Out of curiosity, how much land would you need to make a living?

At least 100 acres.

36. Then did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

Bell Telephone Co., Chicago branch.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1911? What reasons did they have for moving?

Twelve families moved some in 1886 & some in 1895-6. Any weather frost & Prairie fires some went to the Black hills country north of Yorkton started ranching.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not that I remember, many came from 1900 up to 1940. No land now, young people are flocking to the cities.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother Billy was in the Fort Laupille Municipality as a councillor in 1885 & when new was formed into Local Improvement District he was chairman then - later about 1907 we were formed into the municipality of Lipton & he was the first mayor. He was only three years by two different men until 1931/2 when retired. He was also President of the U.G.C. (Lipton Agricultural Society) & also President of the Local Improvement District & President of the Co-op in Lipton. One of the organizers of the Co-op in Lipton & the Lipton Co-op.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first local, etc.)

My Brother bought the first mowing machine (Cutter) north of Fort Laupille in 1885. Before that Alex & I was prime organizers in the 1890's. He was prime organizer for the Rural Telephone Co. in 1918. Also Brother & myself were responsible for having the first meeting called to form the Lipton Co-op around 1938. It is now going strong.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name & occupation of person suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Our Raymond who came in 1883 applied for & got a Post Office & gave his own name for it, without asking his nearly 20 neighbors what they wished to call it. He applied for it in 1886 or 7 and that is why this post office was called Raymond. The Raymond school was built about 1906. Lipton arrived the same year, so the C.P.R. Railway came as far as Lipton & was named by the E.P.R. in 1906. Jumping Puddock was named when we got here, the McDonald Hills lie some 8 miles north west of here & they claim a man named McDonald got lost there & put a stake on the highest hill & cut his name on it. The Southward trail was named when we got here as it was sometimes called the Telegraph Trail.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old poster and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Only old family letters written nearly 100 years ago and an old account book of father's when he was clerk or bookkeeper for some big farmer in Scotland before he came to Canada, and old photographs of the family.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..............

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Now!

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The Railways first, United Grain Growers second and the main thing they worked for for over 45 years before we got it. The Canadian Wheat Board and the putting out of operation that most deplorable business the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, third. The Co-op comes close to it. U.G.G.A and the Wheat Pools and the Canadian Federation of Agriculture, if it had not been for the last named few western member at Ottawa we would not have the Wheat Board yet.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mrs. M. Bailey, Lipton, Sask. Mrs. Miss C.J. Reid, Lipton, Sask.
1869 1853
J.B. Mitchell, Lipton, Sask.
1878

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

P.S. you will see from Hector Andrew Watson the date when this was started, then it got mislaid. It was found about 10 days ago. I was found about 10 days ago. You were supposed to send it as soon as possible. If it was late, turn it or does you like me.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old pictures, old photographs, written recollections, oral recollections (testimonies), old newspapers, old programs, written recollections, oral recollections (testimonies)?

Only our family. They mention nearly 100 years ago and my great-grandfather was born in England.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Would you or the person who owns them either:

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, or to the Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan?

(3) be willing to donate them to the Provincial Archives?

(4) be willing to donate them to the University of Saskatchewan?

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came west?

The railroad first, then the grain elevator, and then the town itself.

Please give the name and address of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If anyone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here.

P.S. You will be from Hector, Saskatchewan.
Oxford

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
